title: 104_s1953
content: The Act titled "Campaign Finance Reform and Disclosure Act of 1996" includes definitions for clarity. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to define "election cycle" and "Senate candidate" for clarity. The term 'campaign expense' refers to an expense solely for a campaign purpose, while 'inherently personal purpose' includes expenses like home mortgage, clothing, noncampaign automobile expenses, vacations, and entertainment not associated with a campaign. The term 'campaign expense' refers to an expense solely for a campaign purpose, while 'inherently personal purpose' includes expenses like home mortgage, clothing, noncampaign automobile expenses, vacations, and entertainment not associated with a campaign. This also includes other personal living expenses determined under a regulation issued under section 326. SEC. 3 and SEC. 4 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 impose limitations on Senate candidates. SEC. 3 restricts out-of-state contributions to 40% of total contributions, while SEC. 4 limits reimbursement for campaign contributions by Senate candidates and their immediate families. SEC. 325 imposes limits on reimbursement for campaign contributions by Senate candidates and their immediate families. SEC. 325 imposes limits on reimbursement for campaign contributions by Senate candidates and their immediate families. The aggregate amount of contributions that may be reimbursed during an election cycle to the candidate or their immediate family is capped at $250,000. Sources include personal funds and loans. The $250,000 limit is adjusted annually based on the price index. Title III of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to add a restriction on the use of campaign funds by Senate candidates for personal purposes. Candidates must use contributions only for legitimate campaign expenses and not for inherently personal purposes. The Federal Election Commission must issue a regulation implementing this restriction within 90 days. This amendment applies to all contributions possessed by a candidate on the date of enactment and thereafter. Additionally, there is a limit imposed on congressional use of the franking privilege. SEC. 6 amends Section 3210(a)(6)(A) of title 39, United States Code, limiting Members of Congress from mailing mass mailings as franked mail during an election year for the seat held by the Member. SEC. 7 decreases PAC contribution limits and indexes limits. SEC. 7 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to decrease PAC contribution limits from $5,000 to $1,000 and indexes the limits annually based on the price index. SEC. 9 prohibits political party committees from accepting contributions that are earmarked for a specific candidate. It also allows unlimited communication between a political party and its members. Section 315(d) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to exclude expenditures made by political party committees for communications to party members from limitations on expenditures. An individual is considered a party member if registered to vote as a party member or has a public record of voting in the party's primary election. The recent primary election allows individuals to indicate in writing that they are a member of a political party. SEC. 10. PROMOTION OF STATE AND LOCAL PARTY ACTIVITY. The amendment to the Federal Election Campaign Act allows State or local party committees to pay for listing party candidates and mailing materials for specific candidates by volunteers. The amendment allows State or local party committees to pay for distributing materials for specific candidates, including collateral materials and conducting telephone banks. State or local party committees can pay for distributing materials for specific candidates, including collateral materials and conducting telephone banks. This includes listing the slate of candidates, mailing materials, conducting telephone banks, and distributing collateral materials. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to allow state or local party committees to pay for distributing materials for specific candidates, excluding payments for volunteer activities. SEC. 11 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to exempt small PACs from reporting requirements if they have not exceeded $25,000 in contributions or expenditures during an election cycle. SEC. 12 addresses employee rights regarding labor organization dues. SEC. 12 amends the National Labor Relations Act regarding the payment of dues to labor organizations for collective bargaining and grievance adjustment. An employee subject to an agreement between an employer and a labor organization requiring the payment of dues may not be required to pay any dues not related to collective bargaining, contract administration, or grievance adjustment necessary for exclusive representation duties unless agreed upon in a written agreement renewed annually. Employees subject to a dues payment agreement must only pay dues related to collective bargaining, contract administration, or grievance adjustment necessary for exclusive representation duties as per a written agreement renewed annually. An employer must post a notice informing employees of their rights under the National Labor Relations Act. The notice clarifies that dues or fees paid to a labor organization as a condition of employment can only be related to collective bargaining, contract administration, or grievance adjustment. Employees must receive a copy of this notice within 10 days of starting employment. The National Labor Relations Act requires employers to post a notice informing employees of their rights, including the limitation on dues or fees paid to a labor organization. Employees subject to such agreements have the right to participate in the organization's affairs related to collective bargaining and contract administration. Labor organizations must disclose expenses related to collective bargaining, contract administration, or grievance adjustment to members or employees paying dues. This requirement aims to ensure transparency in how expenses are classified and attributed within the organization. The Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959 is amended to include employees required to pay dues or fees to the organization in reporting information. The Secretary of Labor must establish regulations for these amendments within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959 is amended to include employees paying dues or fees in reporting. The requirements in the amendments will take effect 60 days after the Act's enactment. SEC. 13. EXPEDITED JUDICIAL REVIEW. (a) Civil Action may be brought by the Federal Election Commission, a political committee, or any eligible individual to challenge the constitutionality of this Act or its amendments. (b) A 3-judge court will be convened promptly for such actions. (c) Appeals from civil actions can be directly made to the Supreme Court. (d) The Supreme Court will conduct expedited reviews. Expedited Review by Supreme Court: The Supreme Court will accept jurisdiction, advance on the docket, and expedite appeals under subsection (c).
